awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Role of Surface Anisotropy in the Cellular Entry of Janus Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1554078
PI: Yu, Yan

Janus particles are specialized particles whose surfaces have two distinct parts with different surface chemistry on each part.  This two-faced feature makes Janus particles especially useful in novel biomedical applications, such as programmed drug delivery, provided the Janus particles can enter cells to carry out their functions.  However, effects of the two-faced feature on cellular entry is not well understood.  The goals of this CAREER project is to elucidate physical principles governing the entry of Janus particles into cells. Results from this project will provide guidance on how to use surface anisotropy to control the entry of synthetic particles into cells, which has the potential to transform the way multifunctional drug delivery particles are designed. The project will also promote interdisciplinary sciences and education at the interface of chemistry, engineering and biology. A Biomaterials Ambassadors outreach program will be established to bring interdisciplinary sciences to K-12 students and teachers in rural communities in Indiana.  This new program will help address the urgent need of improving education in hard-to-reach areas. Visual methods of learning will also be developed to foster critical thinking in undergraduate education. 

This CAREER project will focus on ligand-guided cell entry of Janus microparticles. The hypothesis underlying the project is that the surface anisotropy of Janus particles alters the mechanism of cellular entry by changing the interplay between competing forces. To test this hypothesis, dynamics of Janus spheres will be measured with a new single-particle tracking method, which will reveal particle-cell interactions in multi-dimensions. Cellular dynamics, including membrane deformation and actin protrusion, will be measured with high-resolution fluorescence microscopy. The competition between surface anisotropy and shape in controlling the cellular entry pathways will also be investigated with non-spherical Janus particles. The results will establish a direct and quantitative connection between the particle-level anisotropies and the cell-level responses with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report ? NSF Award # 1554078

Project Title: CAREER: The Role of Surface Anisotropy in the Cellular Entry of Janus Particles

Recipient Organization: Indiana University

Project/Grant Period: 02/15/2016 - 09/30/2022

PI: Yan Yu

 

Janus particles are specialized particles whose surfaces have two distinct parts with different surface chemistry on each part. This two-faced feature makes Janus particles especially useful in novel biomedical applications, such as programmed drug delivery, provided the Janus particles can enter cells to carry out their functions. However, effects of the two-faced feature on cellular entry are not well understood. Results from this research project provided new knowledge to address this important question.

This project has resulted in a total of 11 research publications, highlighted by the development of new imaging techniques and establishment of new knowledge. First and foremost, a major achievement from this project is the development of a series of single-particle rotational imaging and tracking techniques. While most existing single-particle imaging techniques focus on the translational dynamics of particles in non-living or living systems, the capability of tracking the rotation of particles unravels new dimensions of information and opens doors to many new directions. As demonstrated in our research, the Janus particle-based single-particle rotational imaging techniques provided the critical leverage in discoveries of new phenomena and mechanisms in the cell entry process. Second, for new knowledge advancement, findings from this project have established a new understanding of how the surface anisotropy of Janus particles determines their interaction with living cells. Specifically, studies supported by this project revealed that the anisotropic surface presentation of ligands on particles alters the mechanism by which cell membranes engulf and internalize the particles, as well as the kinetics at which the internalized cargos are degraded by cells. Furthermore, this project has resulted in a few key discoveries about the physical mechanisms of cell endocytosis, a process that most drug delivery particles use for successful intracellular delivery. One major discovery is that endosomes ? organelles where internalized cargos are processed and sometimes degraded ? rotate in cells as they are carried by molecules motors that navigate the complex mesh network of the cytoskeleton. The other discovery is how fast endosomes are transported affects how rapidly the internalized contents are degraded. Collectively, these findings provided important insights for multiple research fields. They revealed new knowledge on cell endocytic functions, and on the intracellular fate of particles that are engineered for biomedical applications.

In addition to contribution to research, this project also made significant contribution to the development of human resources. It supported the training of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students, including a large group of women students and underrepresented minority students. The highly interdisciplinary nature of this project provides an ideal platform to prepare students as the future workforce that can tackle grand challenges across disciplines. This project also made a broader impact through a series of educational and outreach work. With partial support from this project, a new undergraduate course titled Chemistry of Art was successfully developed. This course is the first of its kinds at Indiana University. The course curriculum was designed to help non-science major students develop a conceptual understanding of nanotechnology and bio-nano interactions. Furthermore, this project supported the ?Biomaterials Ambassadors? outreach activities to reach K-12 students in rural communities in Indiana.


Last Modified: 01/24/2023
Modified by: Yan Yu
